I do not enjoy this game AT ALL!

The version I played didn't have the bell to signal the start and end of the game so as soon as you get your cards people are shouting to trade.

I like to get my cards in order first (it's an OCD thing) and then start trading - i.e. when the bell is rung and everyone is ready. I find it stressful.

It's also really loud and I don't find it relaxing but actually stress-inducing. Of course I like board games where people get excited and it gets loud at times, but not when it's the core mechanic of the game.

Definitely not for me, sorry, but at least it's over quite quickly if we do play it.

World's liveliest card game. Trade 1! Trade 2! Trade 3! Corner the market.
Pit! is an open-outcry commodity trading game where players offer trades by crying out the number of cards the way to swap (1, 1, 1 or 3, 3, 3) but not their identity. Collect all of one commodity and corner the market to win.
M: Commodity Speculation, Negotiation, Real-Time, Set Collection, Trading

The chaos, shouting, and rush to collect a set of 9 cards is a lot of fun for the first few rounds, but it soon outstays its welcome when you realize the game doesn't end until someone reaches 500 points. Players typically end up trading the same cards over and over again and it's almost pointless trying to collect the the low-scoring commodities when wheat is out there worth 100 points. The bull and bear cards add a nice twist to make the game more interesting, but they don't seem to be implemented well since 2 players have one extra card each round. Overall, this game can be exciting and fun, but it gets boring fast.

Fun times, albeit with a shortened play time (250 or 300 points as opposed to the more traditional 500 to end the game). It could easily overstay its welcome, but is easily enough house ruled to a manageable length.

In all, it's a rather random, social party game; in other words, just my style. The race in each round gives everything a necessary tension, and provides some small decision points around the timing of certain trades. The Bull and Bear cards - a necessity to make the game more amusing and frantic - are only 2 among many in the deck. Yet each round of the game will feature a mini-game of hot potato involving one or both them, which makes for an amusing loss mitigation puzzle amidst the larger goals of the game.

House Rule:
- Play up to 200 points to speed up the game.

Deux, deux, deux!

Un siècle d'existence, déjà, pour l'un des jeux les plus modernes et les plus fous qui soient. le principe est simple: imaginez un jeu de sept familles. Dès que la distribution des cartes est terminées, les joueurs peuvent s'échanger des cartes comme ils veulent, dans le désordre le plus complet. Le premier à avoir une famille a gagné…

Bon, j'exagère un peu, il y a quelques règles. Il y autant de familles que de joueurs. On propose, faces cachées, un certain nombre de cartes identiques. Dès que quelqu'un d'autres proposent le même nombre de cartes, on échange. Quand on a une famille, on tape sur la sonnette, et il y a une pénalité en cas d'erreur… Pour corser le tout, il y a le taureau et l'ours, qui peuvent se mélanger à d'autres cartes. L'un est un mistigri qui fait perdre des points à celui qui l'a lorsque la partie se termine, l'autre un joker qui peut aider à gagner... ou faire perdre des points si un autre gagne.

Voila, c'est tout. Seul reproche: les cartes, de qualité "classique" sont bien fragiles pour un jeu où on se les arrache, et le jeu n'a pas une durée de vie très longue. Donc, gardez la sonnette et, comme moi, refaites vous un jeu en carton épais, filmé des deux côtés, indéchirable. Et profitez en pour rajouter quelques familles, de façon à pouvoir jouer plus nombreux encore…

Il y eut, dans les années 70, une édition française, appelée Cambio, qui était depuis longtemps devenue introuvable. Fort heureusement, une nouvelle édition, dans laquelle les classiques céréales sont remplacées par des bovins, est prévue pour 2008 chez mes amis belges de Repos Prod..

De très nombreux jeux directement inspirés du Pit sont parus ces dernières années - Remmi Demmi, Zaubercocktail, Wheedle, Carambouille. Tous sont amusants à jouer, mais aucun n'a la sauvagerie et l'évidence de l'original.


Two, two, two!

This game is around now for almost a century, and it's still one of the most hectic and modern ones. The idea is th simplest of all: imagine a game of happy families. Deal the cards. Then all players can trade cards as they wish, without any turn order or such bothering rule. The first player with a complete family wins…

Well, OK, there are a few more rules. There are as many families as players. Cards for trade are held face down, and the trade is made as soon as another player holds the same number of cards. When a player has a family, he hits the bell, and there are penalties for those who are wrong. Furthermore, there are two special cards, the bear and the bull. One is wild, but is also a penalty if you don't win, the other is a penalty.

This time, that's all. The only flaw of the game is the cards, that are often treated with great violence. They usually last about ten games before one or another is teared up to pieces. So keep the bell and, like me, make your own card game with heavy cardboard, laminated on both sides, impossible to break or cut. And, by the way, add two or three more familes so that you can play with more people. The more, the merrier…

And if you buy it, buy the "luxus" edition, with the bell. A pit without bell is like a suitcase with no handle. Evenbetter, look for the belgian edition, to be published in 2008, with extra optional rules and noisy funny cows instead of mute and boring cereals.

Many card games directly derived from Pit have been published these last few years. Remmi Demmi, Zaubercocktail, Wheedle, Carambouille are no bad games, and are fun to play, but none of them has the wild evidence and savagery of the original Pit.

Solo tienes que juntar los personajes y ganar!!!!
me encanta la campana, es tan estresante!!!!

An incredible, chaotic and fun party game.

You are trying to corner the market on one commodity through trading with others in the group. The trick is that you do not know what the other people are trading.

The way you trade is to shout out how many cards you are willing to trade, at the same time that everyone else is doing the same. If you can agree to the number of cards you want to trade with someone else, you swap those cards.

But, watch out, if you get the Bear it sinks you 100 points.

This game is great if you have someone that gets overly excited about things during a game because they will tip their hand in the most hilarious ways!

If you like, loud, crazy, chaotic party games, this is a game you will love.

This game is a hit at most game tables I bring it to. My family has been playing pit for decades, as our pit is a set from the 1960's. Simple, fun, and there are few games like it!
A couple of notes about the game
1. It is loud, so if you like quiet games this is not the game for you.
2. It is extremely fast-paced, so if you prefer a slow game, it is also not for you.
3. It can play fewer, but I wouldn't play it with less than 5. 6-8 is certainly the sweet spot, but it can play up to 10 well if you have two different sets of the game.
4. I don't recommend playing with the bull and bear, as it's an additional rule that in my opinion doesn't add much to the game.
5. The initial scoring objective in the rules is about 500 points if I remember correctly. This is hilariously ridiculous as a score to win. The game is a blast, but its sweet spot is about 20 minutes of play per session, 30 tops. I have personally lowered the score needed to win to 150 and feel it works well.
6. Maybe doesn't apply to most, but I play it with English-learning students from other countries(I'm from the U.S.), and they always love it. It is a great game to play if not everyone speaks the same language.
7. Also good to have a calm and slower paced game in your collection that you can play afterwards, because everyone's energy level will be sky high, and everyone will likely just got done being loud, so good to decompress afterwards.
I hope that everyone enjoys!
Trading as a loud party game, and not as a quiet euro game? Sign me up.
